title: How to prove that 30 divides n^5-n, using induction - Quora

response.answer_text: The induction basis is the statement with n=1, i.e. Induction Basis: [math]30 \mid (1^5–1)[/math] As is usually the case, this is a trivial statement, since any numbers divides zero. Induction Step: Assume as induction hypothesis that [math]30 \mid (n^5–n)[/math], and show that then also [math]30 \mid ((n+1)^5–(n+1))[/math] Proof: By the induction hypothesis, [math]n^5–n = 30k[/math] for some integer [math]k[/math] Now, by the binomial theorem: [math] (n+1)^5–(n+1) = n^5 + 5n^4 + 10n^3 + 10n^2 + 5n + 1 - (n+1)[/math] [math]= (n^5-n) + 5n(n^3+2n^2+2n+1) [/math] So all that is need is to show the last term is divisible by 30. We need only show that it is divisible by 2, 3 and 5, since 30 is the least common multiple of these numbers. [math] 5n(n^3+2n^2+2n+1)[/math] is obviously divisible by 5; it is also easily seen to be divisible by 2 (can you see that?). To see that it is divisible by 3, consider each of the cases [math]n \equiv 0,1,2 [/math] modulo 3. So we get that [math](n+1)^5–(n+1)[/math] is divisible by 30, which concludes the induction step and the proof.

I love this exercise ! Lets begin : [math]n^5-n = n(n^4-1)=n(n^2+1)(n^2-1)=n(n^2+1)(n+1)(n-1)[/math] and [math]30=5\times2\times3[/math] So the exercise consist in proving that 2, 3 and 5 divide [math]n(n+1)(n-1)(n^2+1)[/math]. In the case of 2 and 3 it is almost straightforward : [math]n(n+1)(n-1)[/math] is the multiplication of three consecutive numbers, therefore 2 and 3 divide [math]n(n+1)(n-1).[/math] Now to prove that 5 divides [math]n^5-n[/math] you have to condsider the five possible cases in order to take into account every integer there is. So we have to perform five different cases : [math]n=5k[/math] is really quick because we have n in the multiplication. The expression is divided by 5 in this case.[math]n=5k-1[/math] : we take the factor [math](n+1)[/math] and obtain a factor [math]5k[/math] in the multiplication : the expression is divided by 5 in this case also.[math]n=5k+1[/math] is the same than the case just before only we have to consider [math](n-1)[/math] to make 5k appear in the multiplication.[math]n=5k\pm2[/math] : we consider the factor [math](n^2+1)[/math] which becomes [math](5k\pm2)^2+1=25k^2\pm20k+4+1=5(5k^2\pm4k+1)[/math]. So the expression is indeed divided by 5 for [math]n=5k\pm2.[/math]We proved that 5 divided the expression for any integer and that 2 andd 3 also divide said expression. Therefore, 30 divides [math]n^5-n.[/math]
